channel.title: [PI]Friend and I Can't Connect To My Own Server
channel.description: Can anyone help me with this please? I used a no-ip, I put it in the correct spots in client.java, I portforwarded correctly (to my knowledge) and I turned it on with the no-ip thing. When I go to log in with my client, it says "error connecting to server." Please help! Thank you.

item.title: [PI]Friend and I Can't Connect To My Own Server
item.dc:creator: @hunterowner3 hunterowner3
item.description:
@hunterowner3 wrote:

[quote=“Dell, post:12, topic:418485”][quote author=smokin flax link=topic=521025.msg3785509#msg3785509 date=1318818082]
Whoever is running the server connect to 0.0.0.0 whoever is connecting use the no-ip
[/quote]
Whoever is hosting the server can also connect with using the no-ip to check to see if others can log on to the no-ip, the real problem here is that if you believe that you have port forward correctly , then the real problem exists in the no-ip, when you sign up for no-ip and they ask what ip you want to mask with an alternative you must give them your default gateway ip. You can find your default gateway ip by running your cmd box and typing “ipconfig”.

hope that helps, Dell.[/quote]

Thanks Dell, that’s alot of useful info. I’ll be sure to try re-portforwarding with your instructions and tell you if it works.

EDIT: I think it’s a port-forwarding issue. The port should be 43594, right? And the IP that is being masked should be the IP I see at www.whatismyip.com, right? LAstly, my Ipv4 ip address changes constantly, but that still doesn’t answer the fact as to why I can’t connect to the server after I change the Ipv4 address in the portforwarding place. I think I’m going to get a static IP though.

Read full topic
item.source: [PI]Friend and I Can't Connect To My Own Server

item.title: [PI]Friend and I Can't Connect To My Own Server
item.dc:creator: @Dell Dell
item.description:
@Dell wrote:

smokin flax:

Whoever is running the server connect to 0.0.0.0 whoever is connecting use the no-ip

Whoever is hosting the server can also connect with using the no-ip to check to see if others can log on to the no-ip, the real problem here is that if you believe that you have port forward correctly , then the real problem exists in the no-ip, when you sign up for no-ip and they ask what ip you want to mask with an alternative you must give them your default gateway ip. You can find your default gateway ip by running your cmd box and typing “ipconfig”.

hope that helps, Dell.

Read full topic
item.source: [PI]Friend and I Can't Connect To My Own Server

item.title: [PI]Friend and I Can't Connect To My Own Server
item.dc:creator: @Coelho Coelho
item.description:
@Coelho wrote:

Encryption:

This does not work with wireless. I suggest you connect straight to your modem.

There is no difference. You’re still connected to a NAT gateway and are assigned an Internal and External IP.

Read full topic

Encryption:

This does not work with wireless. I suggest you connect straight to your modem.

Yes it does, i have wireless. You my sir, are an idiot. If he is using the source on the computer, 0.0.0.0 is a COMPUTER-LOOP, not network based.

item.title: [PI]Friend and I Can't Connect To My Own Server
item.dc:creator: @Coelho Coelho
item.description:
@Coelho wrote:

Three problem’s may have occurred.

[ol][li]You forgot to compile[/li]
[li]The “client.java” you edited was in the server, not the client[/li]
[li]You failed to port forward correctly[/li][/ol]

Read full topic
